Comm. 227.) it differed from tenure iu frankalmoign, iu this: that, iu case of the tenure hy diviue service, the lord of whom the lauds were holden might distrain for its non-perforniauce, whereas, in case of frankalmoign, the lord has no remedy hy distraint for neglect of the service, but merely a right of complttint to the visitor to correct it. Mozley & whitley

title: Divisa
body: In old English law. A device, award, or decree; also a devise; also bounds or limits of division of a parish or farm, etc. Cowell. Also a court held ou the bound-ary, in order to settle disputes of the tenants

title: Divisible
body: That which is susceptible of being divided

title: Divtsim
body: In old English law. Sever-ally; separately. Bract, fol. 47

title: Division
body: In Eugllsh law. one of the smaller subdivisions of a county. Used in

title: Division Of Opinion
body: In the prac-tice of appellate courts, this term denotes such a disagreement amoug the judges that there is not a majority in favor of uuy one view, and hence uo decision can be rendered on the case. But it sometimes also denotes a division into two classes, one of which may comprise a majority of the Judges ; as •when we speak of a decision having proceed-ed from a “divided court.”

title: Divisional Courts
body: Courts in Eng-land, consisting of two or (in special cases) more judges of the high court of justice, sitting to transact certain kinds of business which cannot be disposed of by one Judge

title: Divisum Imperium
body: UM. Lat A divided jurisdiction. Applied, e. g„ to the jurisdlc-tlon of courts of common law and equity over the same subject 1 Kent, Comm. 366; 4 Steph. Comm. 9

title: Divorce
body: The legal separation of man and wlfe, effected, for cause, by the Judg-rnent of a court, and either totally dissolving the marriage relation, or suspending its ef-fects so far as concerns the cohabitation of the parties. Atherton v. Atherton, 181 U. S. 155, 21 Sup. Ct. 544, 45 L. Ed. 794; Miller v. Miller, 33 Cal. 355; Cast v. Cast, 1 Utah, 112

title: Dixieme
body: Fr. Tenth; the tenth part ord. Mar. llv. 1, tit. 1, art 9

title: Do, Dico, Addico
body: Lat. I give, 1 say, I adjudge. Three words used in the Roman law, to express the ^extent of the civil Juris-diction of the praetor. Do denoted that he gave or granted actions, exceptions, aud judices; dico, that he pronounced judgment; addico, that he adjudged the controverted property, or the goods of the debtor, etc., to the plaintiff. Mackeld. Rom. Law, $ 39

title: Do, Lego
body: Lat I give, I bequeath; or I give and bequeath. The formal words of making a bequest or legacy, in the Roman law. Titio ct Seio hontinem, Stichum do, lego, I give and bequeath to Titlus and Seius my man Stichus. Inst. 2, 20, 8, 30, 31. The expression is literally retained in modern wills

title: Do Ut Des
body: Lat. 1 give that you may give; I give [you] that you may give [me.] A formula in the civil law, constituting a general division under which those contracts (termed “innominate”) were classed in which something was given by one party as a consideration for something given by the other. Dig. 19, 4; Id. 19, 5, 5; 2 Bl. Comm. 444

title: Do Ut Facias
body: Lat I give that you may do; I give [you] that you may do or make [for me.] A formula In the civil law, under which those contracts were classed in which one party gave or agreed to give money, in consideration the other party did or performed certain work. Dig. 19, 5, 5; 2 Bl. Cqmm. 444

title: Docimasia Pulmonum
body: In medical jurisprudence. The hydrostatic test used chiefly in cases of alleged infanticide to de-termlne whether the child was born alive or dead, which consists in immersion of the foetal lungs in water. If they have never been inflated they will sink, but will float lf the child has breathed

title: Doctor
body: A learned man; one qualified to give instruction of the higher order in a science or art; particularly, one who has re-ceived the highest academical degree in his art or faculty, as, a doctor of laws, medicine^ or theology. In colloquial language, however, the term is practically restricted to practitioners of medicine. Harrison v. State, 102 Ala. 170, 15 South. 563; State v. Mc-Knight, 131 N. O. 717, 42 S. E. 580, 59 L. R. A. 187

title: Doctor And Student
body: The title of a work written-by St. Germain in the reign of Henry VIIL in which many principles of the common law are discussed in a popular manner. It is in the form of a dialogue between a doctor of divinity and a student in law, and has always been considered a book of merit and authority. 1 Kent, Comm. 504; Crabb, Eng. Law, 482

title: Doctrine
body: A rule, principle, theory, or tenet of the law; as, the doctrine of mer-ger, the doctrine of relation, etc

title: Doe, John
body: The name of the fictitious plaintiff in the action of ejectment. 3 Stepb. Oomm. 618

title: Doed-Bana
body: In Saxon law. The act-ual perpetrator of a homicide

title: Doer
body: In Scotch law. An agent or at-torney. 1 Kames, Eq. 325

title: Dog-Draw
body: AW. In old forest law. The manifest deprehension of an offender against venison In a forest, when he was found drawing after a deer by the scent of a hound led in his hand; or where a person had wounded a deer or wild beast, by shooting at him, or otherwise, and was caught with a dog drawing after him to receive the same. Manwood, Forest Law, 2, c. 8

title: Dog-Latin
body: The Latin of illiterate persons; Latin words put together on the English grammatical system

title: Dogger
body: In maritime law. A light ship or vessel; dogger-fish, fish brought in ships. Cowell

title: Dogger-Men
body: Fishermen that belong to dogger-ships

title: Dogma
body: In the civil law. A word occasionally used as descriptive of an ordinance of the senate. See Nov. 2, 1, 1; Dig. 27, 1, 6

title: Doing
body: The formal word hy which services were reserved and expressed in old conveyances; as "rendering” (reddendo) was expressive of rent. Perk. c. 10, H 625, 635, 638

title: Doit
body: 1TKIN, or DOIT. A base coin of small value, prohibited by St. 3 Hen. V. c. 1. we still retain the phrase, in the common saying, when we would undervalue a man, that he is not worth a doit. Jacob

title: Dole
body: A part or portion of a meadow is so called; and the word has the general signification of share, portlon, or the llke; as "to dole out” anything among so many poor persons, meanlng to deal or distribute in portlons to them. Holthouse

title: Dools
body: or DOOLS. Slips of pasture left between the furrows of plowed land

title: Dolg
body: Sax. A wound. Spelman

title: Dolg-Bote
body: A recompense for a scar or wound. CoweU

title: Doli
body: Lat. See Dontrs

title: Dollar
body: The unlt employed in the United States in calculating money values. It is coined both in gold and sllver, and is of the value of one hundred cents

title: Dolo
body: In Spanlsh law. Bad or mls-chlevous design, white. New Recop. b. 1, tit L c- 1, f 3

title: Dolus
body: In the clvll law. Guile; de-celtfulness; malicious fraud. A fraudulent address or trick used to deceive some one; a fraud. Dlg. 4, 3, 1. Any subtle contriv-ance by words or acts wlth a design to circumvent. 2 Kent, Comm. 560; Code, 2, 21

title: Dom. Proc
body: An abbreviation of Do-mus Procerum or Domo Procerum; the house of lords in England. Sometimes ex-pressed by the letters D. P

title: Domain
body: The complete and absolute ownership of land; a paramount and in-dlvidual rlght of property in land. People v. Shearer, 30 Cal. 658.. Also the real es

title: Dombec, Domboc
body: (Sax. From dom, judgment, and bec, boc, a book.) Dome-book or doom-book. A name given among the Saxons to a code of laws. Sev-eral of the Saxon kings published dombocs, but tlie most important one was that nttrib-uted to Alfred. Crabb, Com. Law, 7. This is sometimes confounded with the celebrated Domesday-Book. See Dome-Book, Domes-DAY

title: Dome
body: (Sax.) Doom; sentence; judg-fnent. An oath. The homager's oath in the black book of Hereford. Blonnt

title: Dome-Book
body: A book or code said to have been compiled nnder the direction of Alfred, for the general use of the whole kingdom of England; containing, as is sup-posed, the principal maxims of the common law, the penalties for misdemeanors, and the forms of judicial proceedings. It is said to have been extant so late as the reign of Edward IV., but is now lost. 1 Bl. Comm. 64, 65

title: Domesday, Domesday - Book
body: (Sax.) An ancient record made in the time of william the Conqueror, and now remain-ing in the English exchequer, consisting of two volumes of unequal size, containing mi-nute and accurate surveys of the lands in England. 2 Bl. Comm. 49, 50. The work was begun by five justices in each county in 1081, and finished in 1086.

title: Domesmen
body: (Sax.) An inferior kind of judges. Men appointed to doom (judge) in matters in controversy. Cowell. Suitors in a court of a manor in ancient demesne, who are judges there. Blount; whishaw; Termes de ia Ley

title: Domesticus
body: In old European law. A seneschal, steward, or major domo; a judge's assistant; an assessor, (q. v.) Spel-man

title: Domicella
body: In old English law. A damsel. Fleta, llb. 1, c. 20, § 80

title: Domicellus
body: In old English law. A better sort of servant in monasteries; also an appellatlon of a king's bastard

title: Domicile
body: That place in which a man has voluntarily fixed the habitation of hlm-self and family, not for a mere speclal or temporary purpose, hut with the present in-tentlon of maklng a permanent home, untll some unexpected event shall occur to Induce him to adopt some other permanent home. In re Gameau, 127 Fed. 677, 62 C. C. A. 403

title: Domiciled
body: Established in a given domicile; belonging to a given state or jur-lsdiction by right of domicile

title: Domiciliary
body: Pertaining to domicile; relating to one’s domicile. Existing or creat-ed at, or connected with, the domicile of a suitor or of a decedent

title: Domiceliate
body: To establish one’s domicile; to take up one’s fixed residence in a given place. To establish the domicile of another person whose legal residence fol-lows one’s own

title: Domichjation
body: In Spanish law. The acquisition of domiciliary rights and status, nearly equivalent to naturalization, which may be accomplished by belng born in the kingdom, by conversion to the Cath-olic faith there, by taking up a permanent residence in some settlement and marrying a native woman, and by attaching oneself to the soil, purchasing or acquiring real property and possessions. Yates v. Iams, 10 Tex. 168

title: Domicilium
body: Lat Domicile, (q. V

title: Domigerium
body: In old Engllsh law. Power over another; also danger. Bract, t 4, t. 1, c. 10

title: Dame
body: NA, (DAME.) A title given to honorable women, who andently, in their own right of inheritance, held a- barony. Cowell

title: Dominant Tenement
body: A term used in the civil Snd Scotch law, and thence in ours, relating to servitudes, meaning the tenement or subject in favor of which the service is constituted; as the tenement over which the servitude extends is called the “servient tenement” wharton; walker v. Clifford, 128 Ala. 67, 29 South. 588, 86 Am St. Rep. 74 ; Dillman v. Hoffman, 38 wis. 572; Stevens v. Dennett, 51 N. H. 339

title: Dominatio
body: In old English law. Lordship

title: Dominical
body: That whlch denotes the Lord’s day, or Sunday

title: Dominicide
body: The act of killing one's lord or master

title: Dominicum
body: Lat. Domain; dem a in ; demesne. A lordship. That of which one has the lordship or ownership. That which

title: Dominicum Antiquum
body: In old

title: Dominio
body: Sp. In Spanlsh law. A term corresponding to and derlved from the Latin dominium, (q. v.) Dominio alto, eminent domain; dominio directo, immediate ownership; dominio utile, beneficial owner-ship. Hart v. Burnett, 15 Cal. 556

title: Dominton
body: ownership, or right to property. 2 Bl. Comm. 1. Title to an ar-tide of property which arises from the pow-er of disposition and the right of claiming it Beker v. westcott, 73 Tex 129, 11 S. W. 157. “The holder has the dominion of the bill.” 8 East, 579

title: Dominium
body: In the civil and old Eng-lish law. ownership; property in the larg-est sense, including both the right of prop-erty and the right of possession or use

title: Domino Volente
body: Lat The own-er belng willing; with* the consent of the owner

title: Dominus
body: In feudal and eoolcsias-tioal law. A lord, or feudal superlor. Dominus rex, the lord the king; the king's title as lord paramount 1 Bl. Comm. 867. Dominus capitalis, a chlef lord. Dominus medius, a mesne or intermedlate lord. Dominus ligius, liege lord or soverelgn. Id

title: Dominus Litis
body: Lat. Tbe master of the suit; i. e., the person who was really and directly lnterested in the suit as a party, as dlstlngulshed from hls attorney or advocate. Bnt the term is also applied to one who, though not orlglnally a party, has made hlm-self such, hy lnterventlon or otherwlse, and has assumed entlre control* and responsihll-ity for one side, and is treated by the court as liable for costs. See In re Stover, 1 Curt. 201, Fed. Cas. No. 13,507

title: Dominus Navis
body: In the clvll law. The owner of a vessel. Dig- 30, 4, 11, 2

title: Domitje
body: Lat Tame; domesticated; not wild. Applied to domestic animals, in which a man may have an absolute proper-ty. 2 Bl. Comm. 391

title: Dommages Interets
body: In French law. Damages

title: Domo Reparanda
body: A writ that lay for one against his neighbor, by the antid* pated fall of whose house he feared a dam-age and Injury to his own. Reg. Orig. 153

title: Domus
body: Lat. In the civil and old Eng-lish law. A house or dwelling; a habita-tion. Inst 4, 4, 8; Townsh. Pl. 183-185. Bennet v. Bittle, 4 Rawle (Pa.) 342

title: D. P
body: Domns sna oniqne est tntissimnm ro-fngium. To every man his own house is hls safest refuge. 5 Coke, 91b; 11 Coke, 82; 3 Inst. 162. The house of every one is to him as hls castle and fortress, as well for hls defense against injury and violence as for his repose. 5 Coke, 91b; Say. 227; Broom, Max. 432. A man's dwelling-house is his castle, not for his own personal protection merely, but also for the protection of his family and his property therein. Curtis ▼. Hubbard, 4 Hlll (N. Y.) 437.

title: Donatarius
body: A donee; one to whom something is given

title: Donatio
body: Lat A gift A transfer of the title to property to one who receives it without paying for it Vicat. The act by which the owner of a thing voluntarily trans-fers the title and possession of the same from hlmself to another person, withont any con-sideration

title: Donation
body: In ecclesiastical law. A

title: Donative Advowson
body: In ecclesias-tical law. A species of advowson, where the benefice 4s conferred on the clerk by the patron’s deed of donation, without presenta-tlon, institution, or induction. 2 Bl. Comm. 23; Termes de la Ley

title: Donator
body: A donor; one who makes a gift, (donatio

title: Donatorius
body: A donee; a person to whom a gift is made; a purchaser. Bract. foL 13, et seq

title: Donatory
body: The person on whom the king bestows hls right to any forfeiture that has fallen to the crown

title: Done
body: Distinguished from “made." “A 'deed made’ may no doubt mean an ‘Instru-ment made;’ but a ‘deed done’ is not an ‘instrument done,’—it is an ‘act done;* and therefore these words, ‘made and done,’ apply to acts, as weil -as deeds.” Lord Brougham, 4 Bell, App. Cas. 38

title: Donee
body: In old English law. He to

title: Donis, Statute De
body: See De Domis, the Statute

title: Donor
body: In old English law. He by

title: Donum
body: Lat in the civil law. A gift; a free gift. Calvin. Distinguished from munua. Dig. 50, 16, 194

title: Doom
body: In Scotch law. Judicial sen-tence, or judgment The decision or sen-tence of a court orally pronounced by an officer called a “dempster” or “deemster.” In modern usage, criminal sentences still end with the words “which is pronounced for doom.”

title: Doomsday-Book
body: See Domesdat-Book

title: Door
body: The place of usual entrance in a house, or into a room in the house. State V. McBeth, 49 Kan. 584, 31 Pac. 145

title: Dormant
body: Literally, sleeping; hence Inactive; in abeyance; unknown; concealed

title: Dorsum
body: Lat. The back. In dorao recordi, on the back of the record. 5 Coke, 44b

title: Dorture
body: (Contracted from dormiture.) A dormitory of a convent; a place to sleep in

title: Dotage
body: Dotage is that feebleness of the mental faculties -which proceeds from old age. It is a diminution or decay of that in-tellectual power which was once possessed. It is the slow approach of death; of that irrevocable cessation, without hurt or dis-ease, of all the functions which once be-longed to the living animal. The external functions gradually cease; the senses waste away hy degrees; and the mind is imper-ceptibly visited by decay, owing’s Case, 1 Bland (Md.) 389, 17 Am. Dec. 311

title: Dotal
body: Relating to the dos or portion of a woman; constituting her portion; corn-prised in her portion

title: Dotalitium
body: In canon and feudal law. Dower. Spelman, voc. “Doarlumf’ Calvin. 2 Bl. Comm. 129. Used as early as A. D. 841

title: Dotation
body: The act of giving a dowry or portion; endowment in general, including the endowment of a hospital or other charitable institution

title: Dote Assignanda
body: A writ which lay for a widow, when it was judicially as-certained that a tenant to the king was seised of tenements in fee or fee-tall at the day of his death, and that he held of the king in chief. In such case the widow might come iuto chancery, and then make oath that she would not marry without the king’s leave, and then she might have this writ. These widows were called the “klng’s wid-ows.” Jacob; Holthouse

title: Dote Unde Nihil Habet
body: A writ which lies for a widow to whom uo dower has been assigned. 3 Bl. Comm. 182. By 23 & 24 VicL c. 126, an ordinary action commenced by writ of summons has taken its place; bnt it remains in force in the United States. Dower unde nihil habet (which title see

title: Dotis Administratio
body: Admeasurement of dower, where the widow holds more than her share, etc

title: Dotissa
body: A dowager

title: Double
body: Twofold; acting in two capacities or having two aspects; multiplied by two. This term has ordinarily the same meaning in law as in popular speech. The principal compound terms into which it en-ters are noted below

title: Doubles
body: Letters-pa tent Cowell

title: Doubt
body: Uncertainty of mlnd; the ab-sence of a settled opinion or conviction; the attitude of mind towards the acceptance of or belief in a proposition, theory, or statement, in which the judgment is not at rest but inclines alternately to either side. Rowe v. Baber. 93 Ala. 42?, 8 South. 865; Smith v. Railway Co., 143 Mo. 33, 44 S. W. 718 ; west Jersey Traction Co. v. Camden Horse R. Co., 52 N. J. Eq. 452, 29 Atl. 333

title: Doun
body: L. Fr. A gift otherwise writ-ten “don” and “done.” The thirty-fourth chapter of Britton is entitled “De Donna.”

title: Dove
body: Doves are animals ferae natures, and not the subject of larceny unless they are in the owner’s custody; as, for example, in a dove-house, or wheu in the nest before they can fly. Com. v. Chace, 9 Pick. (Moss.) 15, 19 Am. Dec. 348; Ruckmon v. Outwater, 28 N. J. Law, 581

title: Dowable
body: Subject to be charged with dower; as dowable lands

title: Dowager
body: A widow who is endowed, or who has a jointure in lieu of dower. In England, this is a title or addition given to the widows of princes, dukes, earls, and other noblemen, to distinguish them from the wives of the heirs, who have right to bear the title

title: Dower
body: The provision which the law makes for a widow out of the lauds or teue-ments of her husband, for her support and the nurture of her children. Co. Lltt. 30a

title: Dowle Stones
body: Stones dlviding lands, etc. Cowell

title: Dowment
body: In old English law. En-dowment; dower. Grogan v. Garrison, 27 ohio St 61

title: Dowress
body: A woman entitled to dower ; a tenant in dower. 2 P. wms. 707

title: Dowry
body: The property which a woman brings to her husband in marriage; now more commonly called a “portlon.”

title: Dozein
body: L. Fr. Twelve; a person twelve years of age. SL 18 Edw. II.; Bar-ring. ob. St. 208

title: Dozen Peers
body: Twelve peers assembled at the instance of the barons, in the reign of Henry III., to be privy counselors, or rather conservators of the kingdom

title: Drachma
body: A term employed in old pleadings and records, to denote a groat Townsh. Pl. 180.

title: Draco Regis
body: The standard, ensign, or military colors borne in war by the an-clent kings of England, having the figure of a dragon painted thereon

title: Draconian Laws
body: A code of laws prepared by Draco, the celebrated lawgiver of Athens. These laws were exceedingly severe, and the term is now sometimes applied to any laws of unusual harshness

title: Draft
body: The common term for a blll of exchange; as being drawn by one person on another. Hinnemann v. Rosenkack, 39 N. V. 100; Douglass v. wilkeson, 6 wend. (N

title: Draftsman
body: Any one who draws or frames a legal document, e.g., a will, con-veyance, pleading, etc

title: Dragoman
body: An interpreter employed in the east, and particularly at the Turkish court

title: Dram
body: In common parlance, this term means a drink of some substance containing alcohol, something which can produce In-toxicatlon. Lacy v. State, 32 Tex. 228

title: Dramatic Composition
body: In copy-right law. A literary work setting forth a story, incident, or scene from life, in which, however, the narrative is not related, hut is represented by a dialogue and action; may include a descriptive poem set to music, or a pantoinine, but not a composition for musical instruments alone, nor a mere spectacu-lar exhibition or stage dance. Daly v. Palm-er, 6 Fed. Cas. 1132; Carte v. Duff (C. C.) 25 Fed. 183; Tompkins v. Halleck, 133 Mass. 35, 43 Am. Rep. 480; Russell v. Smith, 12 Adol. & El. 236; Martlnettl v. McGuire, 16 Fed. Css. 920; Fuller v. Bemis (C. C.) 50 Fed. 926

title: Draw, V
body: In old oriminal praotioe

title: Drawback
body: In the customs laws, thls term denotes an allowance made by the gov-ernment npon the duties due on Imported merchandise when the importer, instead of selling it here, re-exports it; or the refund-ing of such duties lf already paid. This allowance amounts, in some cases, to the whole of the original duties; In others, to a part only

title: Drawee
body: A person to whom a bill of exchange is addressed, and who is request* ed to pay the amount of mouey therein mentioned

title: Drawer
body: The person making a bill of exchange and addressing It to the drawee. Stevenson v. walton, 2 Smedes & M. (Miss.) 265; winnebago County State Bank v. Hustel, 119 Iowa, 115, 93 N. W. 70

title: Drawing
body: In patent law. A representation of the appearance of material ob-jects by means of lines and marks upon pa-per, card-board, or other substance. Ampt v. Cincinnati, 8 Ohio Dec. 628

title: Drawlatches
body: Thieves; robbers. Cowell

title: Drayage
body: A charge for the transpor-tation of property In wheeled vehlcles, such as drays, wagons, and carts. Soule v. San Franclsco Gaslight Co., 54 Cal. 242

title: Dreit-Dreit
body: Droit-droit. Double1 right. A union of the rlght of possession: and the right of property. 2 B1. Comm. 199

title: Drenges
body: S, or DRENGES. In Saxon, law. Tenants in capite. They are said to; be such as, at the coming of william the Conqueror, being put out of their estates, were afterwards restored to them, on their making it appear that they were the trne owners thereof, and neither in auxilio or consilio against him. Spelman

title: Drengage
body: The tenure by whlch the drenches, or drenges, held thelr lands

title: Drift
body: In mining law. An under-ground passage driven horizontally along the course of a mineralized vein or approxl-mately so. Distinguished from “shaft," which is an opening made at the surface and extending downward Into the earth vertically, or nearly so, npon the vein or in-tended to reach it; and from “tunnel,” which is a lateral or horizontal passage un-derground intended to reach the vein or min-eral deposit, where drifting mny begin. Jur-genson v. Diller, 114 Cal. 491, 46 Pac. 610,. 55 Am. St. Rep. 83

title: Drift-Stuff
body: This term signifies, not goods which are the subject of salvage, but

title: Drinclean
body: Sax. A contribution of tenants, in the time of the Saxons, towards a potation, or ale, provided to entertain the lord, or his steward. Cowell. See Cbb-visabii

title: Drinking-Shop
body: A place where Intoxicating liquors are sold, bartered, or de-livered to be drunk on the premlses. Port-land v. Schmidt, 13 or. 17, 6 Pac. 22L

title: Drip
body: A Bpecies of easement or servitude obligating one man to permit the wa-ter falling from another man's house to fall upon his own land. 3 Kent, Comm. 436

title: Driver
body: one employed in conducting a coach, carriage, wagon, or other vehicle, with hones, mules, or other animals, or a bicycle, tricycle, or motor car, though not a street railroad car. See Davis v. Petrlnovich, 112 Ala. 654, 21 Sonth. 344, 36 L. R. A. 615; Gen. St Conn. 1902, f 2038; Isaacs v. Rail-road Co., 47 N. Y. 122, 7 Am. Rep. 418

title: Drofdenne
body: or DROFDENNE. A grove or woody place where cattle are kept Jacob

title: Drofland
body: Sax. A quit rent, or yearly payment, formerly made by some tenants to the king, or their landlords, for driving thelr cattle through a manor to fairs or markets. Cowell; Blount

title: Droit
body: In Frenob law. Right, jus-tlce, equity, law, the whole body of law; al-so a right

title: Droitural
body: wbat belongs of right; relating to right; as real actions are either droitural or possessory,—droitural when the plaintifT seeks to recover tbe property. Finch, Law, 257

title: Drop
body: In English practice, when the members of a court are equally divided on the argument showing cause against a rule nisi, no order is made, i. e., the rule is nei-ther discharged nor made absolute, and the rule is said to drop. In practice, there be-ing a rlght to appeal, it has been usual to make an order in one way, the Junior judge withdrawing hls judgment wharton

title: Drop-Letter
body: A letter addressed for dellvery in the same dty or district in which it is posted

title: Drove
body: A number of animals collected and driven together in a body; a flock or herd of cattle in process of heing driven; indefinite as to number, but Including at least several. Caldwell v. State, 2 Tex. App. 54; McConvill v. Jersey City, 39 N. J. Law, 43

title: Drown
body: To merge or sink. “In some cases a right of freehold shall drown in a chattel?* Co. Lltt. 266a, 321a

title: Drug
body: The general name of substances used in medicine; any substance, vegetable, animal, or mineral, used in the composition or preparation of medicines. The term is also applied to materials used in dyeing and in chemistry. See Collins v. Banking Co., 79 N. C. 281, 28 Am. Rep. 322; U. S. v. Merck, 66 Fed. 251, 13 C. C. A. 432; Cowl v. U. S. (C. C.) 124 Fed. 475; Insurance Co. v. Flem-ming, 65 Ark. 54, 44 S. W. 464, 39 L. R. A. 789, 67 Am. St. Rep. 900; Gault v. State, 34 Ga 533

title: Druggist
body: A dealer in drugs; one whose business is to sell drugs and medl-cines. In strict usage, this term is to be distinguished from “apothecary.” A drug-gist deals in the uncompounded medicinal substances; the business of an apothecary is to mix and compound them. But in America the two words are used interchangeably, as the same persons usually discharge both functions. State v. Holmes, 28 La. Ann. 767, 26 Am. Rep. 110; Hainline v. Com., 13 Bush (Ky.) 352; State v. Donaldson, 41 Minn. 74, 42 N. W. 781

title: Drummer
body: A term applied to commercial agents who travel for wholesale mer-chants and supply the retail trade with goods, or take orders for goods to be ship-ped to the retail dealer. Robbins v. Shelby County Taxing Dist., 120 U. S. 489, 7 Sup. Ct 592, 30 L. Ed. 694; Singleton v. Fritsch, 4 Lea (Tenn.) 96; Thomas v. Hot Springs, 34 Ark. 557, 36 Am. Rep. 24; Strain v. Chi-cngo Portrait Co. (O. C.) 128 Fed. 835

title: Drungarius
body: In old European law. The commander of a drungus, or band of soldiers. Applied also to a naval command-er. Spelman

title: Drungus
body: In old European law. A band of soldiers, (globus militum.) Spelman

title: Drunk
body: A person is “drunk” wben be is so far under the Influence of liquor that hls passions are visibly excited or his judg-inent impaired, or when his brain is so far affected by potations of liquor that hls in-telligence, sense-perceptions, judgment, con-tinulty of thought or of Ideas, speech, and co-ordination of volition with muscular ac-tion (or some of these faculties or process-es) are impaired or not under normal con-trol. State v. Pierce, 65 Iowa, 85, 21 N. W. 195; Elkin v. Buschner (Pa.) 16 Atl. 104; Sapp v. State, 116 Ga. 182, 42 S. E. 411; Ring v. Ring, 112 Ga. 854, 38 S. E. 330; State v. Savage. 89 Ala. 1, 7 South. 183, 7 L. R. A. 428; Lewis v. Jones, 50 Barb. (N. Y.) 667

title: Drunkard
body: He is a drunkard whose habit it is to get drunk; whose ebriety bas

title: Drunkenness
body: In medical jurisprn-dence. The condition of a man whose mind is affected by the immediate use of intoxi-cating drinks; the state of one who is “drunk." See Drunk

title: Duarchy
body: A form of government where two reign Jointly

title: Dubitans
body: Doubting. Dobbin, J., dubitans. 1 Show. 364

title: Du Bit Ante
body: Doubting. is affixed to the name of a judge, In the reports, to signi-fy that he doubted the decision rendered

title: Dubitatur
body: It is doubted. A word frequently used in the reports to indicate that a point is considered doubtful

title: Dubitavit
body: Doubted. Vaughan, C

title: Ducat
body: A foreign coin, varying in value in different countries, but usually worth about $2.26 of our money

title: Dugatus
body: In feudal and old English law. A duchy, the dignity or territory of a duke

title: Duces Tecum
body: (Lat. Bring with you.) The name of certain species of writs, of which the subpoena duces tecum is the most usual, requiring a party who is summoned to appear in court to bring with him some doc-ument, piece of evidence, or other thing to be used or inspected by the court

title: Duces Tecum Licet Languidus
body: (Bring with you, although sick.) In practice. An ancient writ, now obsolete, directed to the sheriff, upon a return that he could not bring his prisoner without danger of death, he being adeo languidus, (so sick;) where-upon the court granted a habeas corpus in the nature of a duces tecum licet languidus. Cowell; Blonnt

title: Duchy Of Lancaster
body: Those lands which formerly belonged to the dukes of Lancaster, and now belong to the crown in right of the duchy. The duchy is distinct from the county palatine of Lancaster, and lncludes not only the county, but also much territory at a distance from It, especlally the Savoy in London and some land near west-minster. 3 Bl. Comm. 78

title: Ducking-Stool
body: See Castioatobt

title: Ducroire
body: In French law. Gnaron-ty; equlvalent to del credere, (whlch see

title: Dub-Bill
body: A brief written acknowledgment of a debt. It is not made payable to order, like a promissory note. See Feeser

title: Duellum
body: The trlal by battel or jndl-clal combat See Battel

title: Dues
body: Certain payments; rates or taxes. See ward v. Joslin, 105 Fed. 227, 44 C. C

title: Duke Of Exeter'S Daughter
body: The name of a rack in tbe Tower, so called after a minister of Henry VI. who sought to introduce it into England.

title: Dulocracy
body: A government where servants and slaves have so much license and privilege that they domineer, wharton

title: Duly
body: In due or proper form or man-ner; according to legal requirements

title: Dumb-Bidding
body: In sales at auction, when the minimum amount which the owner will take for the article is written on a piece of paper, and placed by the owner under a candlestick, or other thing, and it is agreed that no bidding shall avail unless equal to that, this is called “dumb-bidding.” Bab. Auct 44

title: Dummodo
body: Provided; provided that A word of limitation in the Latin forms of conveyances, of frequent use in introducing a reservation; as in reserving a rent

title: Duna
body: In old records. A bank of earth cast up; the side of a ditch. Cowell

title: Dungeon
body: Such an under-ground pris-on or cell as was formerly placed in the strongest part of a fortress; a dark or sub-terraneous prison

title: Dunio
body: A double; a kind of base coin less than a farthing

title: Dunnage
body: Pieces of wood placed against the sides and bottom of the hold of a vessel, to preserve the cargo from the effect of leakage, according to its nature and qual-ity. Abh. Shipp. 227

title: Dunsets
body: People that dwell on hilly places or mountains. Jacob

title: Duodecemvtrale Judicium
body: The

title: Duodecima Manus
body: Twelve hands. The oaths of twelve men, including hlmself, by whom the defendant was allowed to make his law. 8 BL Comm. 343

title: Duodena
body: In old records. A jury of twelve men. Cowell

title: Duodena Manu
body: A dozen hands, i. e., twelve wltnesses to purge a criminal of on ofTense

title: Dupla
body: In the civil law. Double the price of a thing. Dig. 21, 2, 2

title: Duplex Querela
body: A donble com-plalnt An ecclesiastical proceeding, which is in the nature of an appeal from an ordi-nary’s refusal to institute, to hls next im-mediate superior; as from a bishop to the archbishop. If the superior adjudges the cause of refusal to be insufficient, he will grant institution to the appellant Phillim. Ecc. Law’, 440

title: Dulpex Valor Maritagii
body: In oid

title: Duplicatio
body: In the civU law. The defendant’s answer to the plaintiff’s replica-tion; corresponding to the rejoinder of the common law

title: Duplicatum Jus
body: Double right

title: Duplicity
body: The technical fault, in pleading, of uniting two or more causes of action in one count in a writ, or two or more grounds of defense in one plea, or two or more breaches in a replication, or two or more offenses in the same count of an in-dictment. Tucker v. State, 6 Tex. App. 253; waters v. People, 104 IH. 547; Mullin v, Blumenthal, 1 Pennewill (Del.) 476, 42 Atl. 175; Devlno v. Railroad Co., 63 Vt. 98, 20 AU. 953; Tucker v. Ladd, 7 Cow. (N. Y.) 452

title: Durante
body: Lat During. A word of limltation in old conveyances. C0. Litt 234b

title: Durbar
body: In India. A court, audience, or levee. Mozley & whitley

title: Duressor
body: one who subjects another to duress; one who compels another to do a thlng, as by menace. Bac. Max. 90, reg. 22

title: Durham
body: A county palatine in Eng-land, the Jurisdictlon of which was vested in the Bishop of Durham until the statute 6 & 1 Vfm. IV. c. 19, vested it as a separate franchlse and royalty in the crown. The Jurisdiction of the Durham court of pleas was transferred to the supreme court of judlca-ture by the Judicature act of 1873. 1

title: Dursley
body: In old English law. Blows wlthout wounding or bloodshed; dry blows. Blount

title: Dustuck
body: A term used in Hlndostan for a passport, permit, or order from the English East Indian Company. It generr ally meant a permit under their seal exempting goods from the payment of duties. Enc. Lond

title: Dutch Auction
body: See Auction

title: Duty
body: In lts use in jurisprudence, this word is the correlative of right. Thus, wherever there exists a right in any person, there also rests a corresponding duty upon

title: Duumviri
body: (From duo, two, and viri, men.) A general appellation among the an-cient Romans, given to any magistrates elect-ed in pairs to fill any office, or perform any function. Brande

title: D. W
body: I. In genealogical tables, a com-mon abbrevlation for “died wlthout issue.”

title: Dwell
body: To have an abode; to lnhablt; to live in a place. Gardener v. wagner, 9 Fed. Cas. 1,154; Ex parte Blumer, 27 Tex. 736; Putnam v. Johnson, 10 Mass. 502; Ea-tontown v. Shrewsbury, 49 N. J. Law, 188, 6 Atl. 319

title: Dwelling-House
body: The house in which a man lives with his family; a resi-dence; the apartment or building, or group of buildings, occupied by a family as a place of residence

title: Dwelling-Place
body: This term is not synonymous with a “place of pauper settlement.” Lisbon v. Lyman, 49 N. H. 553

title: Dying Declaration
body: See Decla-bation

title: Dying Without Issue
body: At common law this phrase imports an indefinite failure of issue, and not a dying without is-sue surviving at the time of the death of the first taker. But this rule has been changed in some of the states, by statute or decisions, and in England by St. 7 wm. IV., and 1 Vict. c. 26, § 29

title: Dysnomy
body: Bad legislatlon; the enactment of bad laws

title: Dyspareunla
body: In medical Jurisprudence. Incapacity of a woman to sustain the act of sexual intercourse except with great difficulty and paln

title: Dyspesia
body: A state of the stomach in which Its functions are disturbed, without the presence of other diseases, or when, if other diseases are present, they are of minor importance. Dungl. Med. Dict

title: Dyvour
body: In Scotch law. A bankrupt

title: Damages
body: Money that a defendant pays a plaintiff in a civil case if the plaintiff has won. Damages may be compensatory (for loss or injury) or punitive (to punish and deter future misconduct).

title: De facto
body: Latin, meaning "in fact" or "actually." Something that exists in fact but not as a matter of law.

title: De jure
body: Latin, meaning "in law." Something that exists by operation of law.

title: De novo
body: Latin, meaning "anew." A trial de novo is a completely new trial. Appellate review de novo implies no deference to the trial judge's ruling.

title: Debtor's plan
body: A debtor's detailed description of how the debtor proposes to pay creditors' claims over a fixed period of time.

title: Debtor
body: A person who has filed a petition for relief under the Bankruptcy Code.

title: Declaratory judgment
body: A judge's statement about someone's rights. For example, a plaintiff may seek a declaratory judgment that a particular statute, as written, violates some constitutional right.

title: Default judgment
body: A judgment awarding a plaintiff the relief sought in the complaint because the defendant has failed to appear in court or otherwise respond to the complaint.

title: Defendant
body: An individual (or business) against whom a lawsuit is filed.

title: Deposition
body: An oral statement made before an officer authorized by law to administer oaths. Such statements are often taken to examine potential witnesses, to obtain discovery, or to be used later in trial. See discovery.

title: Discharge
body: A release of a debtor from personal liability for certain dischargeable debts. Notable exceptions to dischargeability are taxes and student loans. A discharge releases a debtor from personal liability for certain debts known as dischargeable debts and prevents the creditors owed those debts from taking any action against the debtor or the debtor's property to collect the debts. The discharge also prohibits creditors from communicating with the debtor regarding the debt, including through telephone calls, letters, and personal contact.

title: Dischargeable debt
body: A debt for which the Bankruptcy Code allows the debtor's personal liability to be eliminated.

title: Disclosure statement
body: A written document prepared by the chapter 11 debtor or other plan proponent that is designed to provide "adequate information" to creditors to enable them to evaluate the chapter 11 plan of reorganization.

title: Discovery
body: Procedures used to obtain disclosure of evidence before trial.

title: Dismissal with prejudice
body: Court action that prevents an identical lawsuit from being filed later.

title: Dismissal without prejudice
body: Court action that allows the later filing.

title: Disposable income
body: Income not reasonably necessary for the maintenance or support of the debtor or dependents. If the debtor operates a business, disposable income is defined as those amounts over and above what is necessary for the payment of ordinary operating expenses.

title: Docket
body: A log containing the complete history of each case in the form of brief chronological entries summarizing the court proceedings.

title: Due process
body: In criminal law, the constitutional guarantee that a defendant will receive a fair and impartial trial. In civil law, the legal rights of someone who confronts an adverse action threatening liberty or property.
